head.title: Reactive Species and Reaction Pathways for the Oxidative Cleavage of 4-Octene and Oleic Acid with H2O2 over Tungsten Oxide Catalysts | ACS Catalysis

meta.content: Reactive Species and Reaction Pathways for the Oxidative Cleavage of 4-Octene and Oleic Acid with H2O2 over Tungsten Oxide Catalysts

Oxidative cleavage of carbon–carbon double bonds (C═C) in alkenes and fatty acids produces aldehydes and acids valued as chemical intermediates. Solid tungsten oxide catalysts are low cost, nontoxic, and selective for the oxidative cleavage of C═C bonds with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and are, therefore, a promising option for continuous processes. Despite the relevance of these materials, the elementary steps involved and their sensitivity to the form of W sites present on surfaces have not been described. Here, we combine in situ spectroscopy and rate measurements to identify significant steps in the reaction and the reactive species present on the catalysts and examine differences between the kinetics of this reaction on isolated W atoms grafted to alumina and on those exposed on crystalline WO3 nanoparticles. Raman spectroscopy shows that W–peroxo complexes (W–(η2-O2)) formed from H2O2 react with alkenes in a kinetically relevant step to produce epoxides, which undergo hydrolysis at protic surface sites. Subsequently, the CH3CN solvent deprotonates diols to form alpha-hydroxy ketones that react to form aldehydes and water following nucleophilic attack of H2O2. Turnover rates for oxidative cleavage, determined by in situ site titrations, on WOx–Al2O3 are 75% greater than those on WO3 at standard conditions. These differences reflect the activation enthalpies (ΔH‡) for the oxidative cleavage of 4-octene that are much lower than those for the isolated WOx sites (36 ± 3 and 60 ± 6 kJ·mol–1 for WOx–Al2O3 and WO3, respectively) and correlate strongly with the difference between the enthalpies of adsorption for epoxyoctane (ΔHads,epox), which resembles the transition state for epoxidation. The WOx–Al2O3 catalysts mediate oxidative cleavage of oleic acid with H2O2 following a mechanism comparable to that for the oxidative cleavage of 4-octene. The WO3 materials, however, form only the epoxide and do not cleave the C–C bond or produce aldehydes and acids. These differences reflect the distinct site requirements for these reaction pathways and indicate that acid sites required for diol formation are strongly inhibited by oleic acids and epoxides on WO3 whereas the Al2O3 support provides sites competent for this reaction and increase the yield of the oxidative cleavage products.

div.div:
Oxidative cleavage of the double bonds within alkenes and unsaturated fatty acids (UFA) provides pathways to reactive aldehyde, acid, and diacid intermediates useful for chemical synthesis. For example, nonanal, azeladehydic acid, azelaic acid, and pelargonic acid form by oxidative cleavage of oleic acid, and these medium chain length saturated aldehydes and acids find use in the preparation of polymers (Nylon-6:9), plasticizers, adhesives, and lubricants.
(1−4)
Ozonolysis leads among current industrial methods for oxidative cleavage due to its high selectivity,
(5)
however, this chemistry involves the use of hazardous compounds (O
3
, metal-free process) and carries high capital costs and significant energy demands.
(6−8)
These drawbacks motivate the research and development of alternative chemistries of oxidative cleavage.

Reactions of transition metal-based catalysts with hydrogen peroxide (H
2
O
2
), a comparably benign oxidant, offer a replacement for ozonolysis. Soluble molecular complexes that contain Fe,
(1,9)
Os,
(10,11)
Co,
(12)
Mo,
(13)
W,
(2,13−15)
or Ru
(16−18)
activate H
2
O
2
and give significant turnover numbers and yield for the oxidative cleavage of alkenes and unsaturated fatty acids. Among these elements, tungsten-based catalysts, including WO
3
, W-based polyoxometallates, and tungstic acid, provide low toxicity and cost,
(19)
high stability compared to Fe, Co, and Mo complexes,
(1)
and appreciable rates for hydrogen peroxide-mediated oxidation.
(20,21)
Oguchi et al.
(22)
reported that reactions of cyclohexene with stoichiometric quantities of H
2
O
2
over tungstic acid (H
2
WO
4
, with a molar ratio of cyclohexene to H
2
WO
4
of ∼2) or tungstophosphoric acid (H
3

12
O
40
, with a molar ratio of cyclohexene to H
3
PW
12
O
40
equal to ∼25) give adipic acid yields of 62% and 50%, respectively (
tert
-butanol, 356 K, 24 h). Turnwald et al.
(13)
reported the oxidative cleavage of neat oleic acid with an excess of H
2
O
2
over peroxo-tris(cetylpyridinium) tungstophosphate (H
2
O
2
-activated (π-C
5

)

with a molar ratio of oleic acid to catalyst of 77), which gave a 57% yield of azelaic acid and nonanoic acid (363 K, 5 h); however, the catalyst could not be regenerated. In comparison, the cesium form of the same catalyst (peroxo-tri(cesium)12-tungstophosphate, H
2
O

3
(PW

, molar ratio of oleic acid to catalyst of 77) was stable but provided a lower yield of azelaic acid (28%, 363 K, 10 h).
(13)
The sodium salt of tungstic acid (Na
2
WO
4
) was used by Noyori et al.
(23)
to convert cyclohexene to adipic acid with a high yield (93%, molar ratio of cyclohexene to catalyst equal to 100, neat cyclohexene, 363 K, 8 h) when combined with a phase transfer catalyst (PTC, (CH
3
(

8

)

4
, molar ratio of PTC to Na
2
WO
4
of 1). Although these prior studies demonstrate that W-based homogeneous complexes are competent catalysts for oxidative cleavage reactions with H
2
O
2
, the solubility of these complexes introduces significant challenges for large-scale processes. Consequently, several groups have examined heterogeneous tungstate catalysts for liquid-phase oxidative cleavage reactions with H
2
O
2
, yet reported selectivities are much lower than homogeneous W catalyst. Silica-supported WO
3
only yields 30% azelaic acid and nonanoic acid from oleic acid.
(6)
WO
3
catalyst promoted with Na
2
SnO
3
gives a 90% yield of the desired acids (at 100% conversion) from oxidative cleavage of oleic acid; however, WO
3
in the absence of cocatalyst is much less effective (60% acid yield).
(24)

The reasons for the lower rates and selectivities for oxidative cleavage over solid tungstate catalysts remain uncertain due, in part, to a lack of knowledge regarding the elementary steps involved in oxidative cleavage reactions on these materials and their kinetic relevance, the identity of the reactive species, and the form of the active W complexes.
Scheme 1
shows the sequence of stoichiometric reactions generally accepted for the H
2
O
2
-mediated oxidative cleavage of alkenes. Antonelli et al.
(25)
proposed that the reaction proceeds by epoxidation of the alkene followed by hydrolysis of the oxirane ring to yield the diol. Subsequently, deprotonation of the diol produces an alpha-hydroxy ketone intermediate susceptible to nucleophilic attack by H
2
O
2
that cleaves the C–C bond and forms aldehyde products. Finally, additional equivalents of H
2
O
2
oxidize the aldehydes to yield the carboxylic acids. Oxidative cleavage of unsaturated fatty acids likely involves similar steps as mechanisms for cyclo- or linear alkenes; however, the relative rates of these steps and therefore the distribution of the products may differ as a result of the terminal carboxylic acid function on the reactant and its impact on the prevailing intermediates bound to the active sites.
(1)
We are not aware of prior investigations that have measured and molecularly interpreted the effects of reactant concentrations on product formation rates for linear alkenes and unsaturated fatty acid oxidative cleavages over solid catalysts.
Scheme 1. Commonly Proposed Stoichiometric Reactions Involved in the Oxidative Cleavage of Unsaturated Carbon–Carbon Bonds in Linear Alkenes

In addition, the structural heterogeneity among plausible active sites on many forms of solid tungstate catalysts complicates efforts to identify reactive intermediates. Prior work indicates that reactive tungsten–peroxo complexes (W–(η
2
-O
2
)) form by activation of H
2
O
2
on coordinatively unsaturated W atoms (e.g., tetrahedrally coordinated, isolated W atoms) as opposed to more highly coordinated W atoms within continuous tungstate domains.
(26−28)
Hammond et al.,
(29)
however, compared cyclooctene epoxidation rates upon WO
3
nanoparticles and W–Zn/SnO
2
catalysts and concluded that crystalline WO
3
is the most active and stable phase for H
2
O
2
-mediated epoxidation, not mono- or polytungstates.

Here, we examine reactive intermediates, reaction mechanisms, and the effects of the active site structure for the oxidative cleavage of 4-octene and oleic acid over supported and unsupported tungsten oxide catalysts. We synthesized WO
x
complexes on γ-Al
2
O
3
with varying extents of dispersion by surface grafting methods. Raman, UV–vis, and XRD indicate that this method forms materials that possess predominantly monomeric and dimeric WO
x
species at the lowest W surface coverages under the reaction conditions. A combination of kinetic measurements and in situ spectroscopy demonstrates that the surface chemistry and catalysis on these WO
x
sites resembles that of crystalline WO
3
nanoparticles; however, reaction rates and activation barriers differ significantly. In situ Raman and UV–vis spectroscopies suggest W–peroxide complexes (i.e., W–peroxo (W–(η
2
-O
2
)) and W–hydroperoxo (W–OOH)) both participate in steps for oxidative cleavage and form by activation of H
2
O
2
-exposed W atoms. Rate measurements as functions of the concentrations of the organic substrates, H
2
O
2
, and the epoxide intermediates reveal that oxidative cleavage involves kinetically relevant epoxidation of the alkene on W–(η
2
-O
2
) and ring opening of the epoxide to form a diol on acidic sites (W–OOH). Subsequent steps that cleave the diol and yield aldehyde and acid products occur by reactions with the solvent (CH
3
CN) and H
2
O
2
in the liquid phase. The apparent activation enthalpies (
ΔH
‡
) for oxidative cleavage of 4-C
8
H
16
on WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
are 24 kJ·mol
–1
lower than those on WO
3
, and the turnover rates on isolated WO
x
sites are 75% greater at standard reaction conditions. The differences between
ΔH
‡
on these catalysts correlate with differences in the Lewis acid strength of these active sites and their enthalpies of adsorption for the epoxide intermediate (
ΔH
ads,epox
) as measured by isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC). These comparisons suggest that the isolated W sites give greater turnover rates, particularly at lower reaction temperatures, because alumina-supported WO
x
species possess greater electronegativities, bind epoxide products more strongly, and stabilize kinetically relevant transition states more effectively than W atoms exposed to WO
3
. More consequential differences between turnover rates and selectivities were observed during oleic acid conversion over WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
and WO
3
catalysts. Particles of WO
3
mainly produce the epoxide of oleic acid, while isolated WO
x
sites give high selectivities for oxidative cleavage products. These differences reflect the limited number of protons on the WO
3
surface and strong inhibition of the active sites by the carboxylic acid and the epoxide intermediate, both of which contribute to low rates for diol formation and oxidative cleavage. An abundance of protons on the W sites (W–OOH) of WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
facilitates hydrolysis of the epoxide and gives higher turnover rates for aldehyde and acid production.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Two forms of tungsten oxide catalysts were used in this work. Disperse W atoms were prepared on the surface of mesoporous alumina by grafting organotungsten complexes.
(30)
Aluminum oxide (γ-Al
2
O
3
, Sigma-Aldrich; 3.8 nm pores, 364 m
2
·g
–1
) was calcined in flowing air (Airgas, Ultra Zero grade) at 823 K for 6 h with the intent to remove organic residues and moisture. The cooled solid (∼1 g) was added to chloroform (120 cm
3
; CHCl
3
, TCI Chemical, ≥99.0%) within a two-neck round-bottom flask under Ar (Airgas, 99.999%) flow in a glass air-free apparatus. The mixture was stirred for 0.5 h (300 rpm, ∼295 K), after which bis(cyclopentadienyl)tungsten dichloride ((C
5
H
5
)
2
WCl
2
, Alfa Aesar, 99%) was added as a dry powder into a suspension of alumina in CHCl
3
. The mixture was stirred under continuous Ar purge for 0.5 h. Then 3 equiv of triethylamine ((C
2
H
5
)
3
N, Sigma-Aldrich, 99.5%) was added to the mixture to deprotonate the surface hydroxyls and adsorb (C
5
H
5
)
2
WCl
2
. The mixture was stirred for another 12 h. Subsequently, the solids were filtered, dried, and calcined at 823 K for 6 h in flowing air (100 cm
3
·min
–1
; Airgas, Ultra Zero grade) to form tungsten oxide complexes (WO
x
) on the alumina. The resulting WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
materials were characterized (vide infra) and denoted by the areal density of W atoms on the Al
2
O
3
surface (
X
-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
, where
X
is the number of W atoms per square nanometer (W·nm
–2
)). Tungsten oxide nanoparticles (WO
3
) were purchased (US Research Nanomaterials, US3538, 60 nm mean diameter) and used as received.

Adsorption and desorption isotherms of N
2
were performed using a Micrometrics 3Flex analyzer and SmartVac degasser. Catalyst (<50 mg) was loaded into a glass vessel and heated under vacuum to desorb water and organic residues. The degassed sample was weighed, and then the isotherms were obtained. The N
2
adsorption–desorption isotherm of the γ-Al
2
O
3
calcined at 823 K for 6 h shows a type IV isotherm with H1-type hysteresis. The total surface areas of these samples were determined to be 281 m
2
·g
–1
using the BET method. The N
2
adsorption–desorption isotherm of the WO
3
nanoparticles exhibits hysteresis loops at 0.9–1.0 relative pressure due to the textural porosity of the nanoparticles, and the BET surface area of the WO
3
nanoparticles was found to be 11 m
2
·g
–1
.

Energy-dispersive X-ray fluorescence (EDXRF) was conducted to determine the composition of the synthesized catalysts (
Table
1
). Powder samples were loaded into the He-purged chamber of the spectrometer (EDX-7000, Shimadzu) and scanned from 0 to 30 keV.

div.h3: 2.3. In Situ Raman and UV–vis Spectroscopy
div.div:
In situ Raman spectroscopy was used to examine the structure of the tungsten oxide domains in the dehydrated catalysts and the reactive species formed by contact with aqueous H
2
O
2
solutions. Raman spectra of the dehydrated catalysts were obtained from catalyst pellets placed in an environmentally controlled high-temperature cell reactor (Linkam, CCR1000). Before analysis, the catalysts were dehydrated at 823 K for 1 h in flowing O
2
(Airgas, ultrahigh purity, 20 cm
3
min
–1
) to desorb the adsorbed moisture. The spectra were collected after cooling the catalyst to room temperature in flowing O
2
gas (20 cm
3
·min
–1
). Spectra were acquired with a Raman spectrometer (Renishaw, inVia) equipped with a 532 nm laser that was less than 41 mW·μm
–2
at the catalyst surface. The power density was measured directly using a portable power meter (Gentec-EO, PRONTO-Sl). Experimental spectra represent the average of 1000 accumulations with 0.1 s per accumulation.

The Raman spectra of the catalysts under the reaction conditions were taken within a custom liquid flow cell. The pelletized catalysts were placed in this cell, immersed in flowing acetonitrile solutions (CH
3
CN, Fischer Chemicals, HPLC grade), and heated to 313 K. Steady-state spectra of the reactive intermediates were collected (0.1 s per accumulation, 1000 accumulations) in flowing solutions of H
2
O
2
and CH
3
CN (0.5 M H
2
O
2
, 1.98 M H
2
O, 313 K) delivered by an HPLC pump (SSI, LS Class; 1 cm
3
min
–1
). Spectra were acquired using a 532 nm laser with areal power density (5.2 mW·μm
–2
for
X
-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
and 0.2 mW·μm
–2
for WO
3
).

In situ UV–vis spectra were collected using a 45° diffuse reflection probe (Avantes, solarization-resistant fibers) coupled to a fiber-optic spectrometer (Avantes, AvaFast 2048) with a compact deuterium–halogen light source (Avantes, AvaLight-DHc). The pelletized catalyst was loaded into a similar liquid flow cell as used for Raman spectra but equipped with a sealed port to admit the diffuse reflectance probe. The sample was contacted with flowing aqueous CH
3
CN (1.98 M H
2
O in CH
3
CN, 1 cm
3
·min
–1
) and heated to 313 K while continuously scanning. Background spectra were obtained when the system reached steady state. The spectra of the reactive species were collected when samples contacted flowing H
2
O
2
solutions (0.5 M H
2
O
2
, 1.98 M H
2
O in CH
3
CN, 1 cm
3
·min
–1
) at 313 K, and the system was allowed to reach steady state once more. Subsequently, the solution was switched to pure CH
3
CN (1 cm
3
·min
–1
) to determine if the H
2
O
2
-activated species on these catalysts form reversibly. All UV–vis spectra of H
2
O
2
-derived intermediates represent the difference between the experimental spectrum (i.e., sample within aqueous H
2
O
2
solutions) and the background spectrum obtained within aqueous CH
3
CN in the absence of H
2
O
2
.

Rates for oxidative cleavage of oleic acid (C
18
H
34
O
2
, TCI Chemical, >99%) and 4-octene (
trans
-4-C
8
H
16
, Sigma-Aldrich, 98%) were measured within batch reactors (100 cm
3
, three-neck round-bottom flasks) equipped with reflux condensers. The organic reactant was combined with hexane (an internal standard for GC analysis, C
6
H
14
, Sigma-Aldrich, ≥95%) and the catalyst (30–100 mg) and added to CH
3
CN. The mixture was heated to the desired temperature (313–343 K) and stirred at 700 rpm for 0.5 h. The reaction was initiated by adding the necessary amount of aqueous H
2
O
2
(Fischer Chemicals, 30% in H
2
O). Aliquots (∼0.8 cm
3
) of the reaction solution were extracted as a function of reaction time using a syringe equipped with a filter (0.05 μm, polystyrene for WO
3
, 0.22 μm, polypropylene for
X
-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
) to separate the catalyst particles from the reaction solution. Analogous approaches were used to determine the reaction rates for epoxide ring opening and the oxidative cleavage of diols. The aliquots were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890A) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). Reactants and products were separated in a column (HP-INNOWax, 30 m × 0.53 mm i.d., 1.0 μm film thickness). Peaks within the gas chromatograms were identified by comparisons to mixtures of known standards and with a mass-selective detector (MSD, Agilent, 5975B) operating with electron ionization. The alkene conversion and product selectivity were calculated as follows

Analysis of pseudosteady-state turnover rates for oxidative cleavage as a function of reactant concentration is reported on the basis of moles of carbon within the products normalized by the number of active sites (
Section 2.5
) per unit time (i.e., (mol C)(mol W·s)
−1
). Reactions of 4-octene with H
2
O
2
give selectivity to butanal of ∼95% over both WO
3
and WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalysts at the reaction conditions and low conversions examined here. Therefore, moles of carbon within produced butanal are used to determine turnover rates for oxidative cleavage. Carbon balances for reactions with 4-octene are typically 85–95%. Reaction with oleic acid, however, gave different selectivities to epoxide (i.e., 8-(3-octyloxiran-2-yl)octanoic acid) and oxidative cleavage products (i.e., nonanal, nonanoic acid, 9-oxo-nonanoic acid, azelaic acid) over WO
3
and WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalysts. Over WO
3
, selectivity for epoxide is greater than 98% and selectivity for oxidative cleavage products is less than 2%. On the other hand, selectivity for oxidative cleavage products is greater than 80% over WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalyst. Turnover rates for oleic acid consumption were determined from the sum of the formation rates for all detected products (i.e., 8-(3-octyloxiran-2-yl)octanoic acid, nonanal, nonanoic acid, 9-oxo-nonanoic acid, and azelaic acid) over both catalysts. Carbon balances for reactions with oleic acid are 60–80% and are systematically lower than for reactions with 4-octene.

The concentration of H
2
O
2
was measured by colorimetric titration using a titrant solution which is an aqueous solution of CuSO
4
(8.3 mM, Fisher Chemicals, >98.6%), neocuproine (12 mM, Sigma-Aldrich, >98%), and ethanol (25% v/v, Decon Laboratories, 100%). The reaction solution was diluted to 1–10% v/v reaction solution with CH
3
CN. The diluted reaction solution (10 μL) was titrated with the titrant (0.2 cm
3
), and the absorbance at 454 nm was determined using a multidetection microplate reader (BioTek, Synergy 2). The measured H
2
O
2
concentration values were used to calculate H
2
O
2
decomposition rates.

We carried out a hot filtration test for WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalyst to determine if active WO
x
species are leaching from the alumina support (
Section S1.1
). During a reaction, an aliquot of the reaction mixture (8 cm
3
) was taken by syringe at 30 min, the solid catalyst was filtered, and the liquid solution was transferred into a 20 cm
3
scintillation vial (700 rpm, 333 K). Aliquots were taken from the batch reactor and scintillation vial as a function of time, and concentrations of reactant and products were measured by gas chromatography. The concentrations of butanal do not change following filtration of the catalyst (
Figure S1
), which indicates that the active WO
x
species do not leach from the alumina support and catalyze reactions in the solution.

WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalysts are stable and regenerable, which was established by conducting four subsequent batch reactions, each followed by an oxidative catalyst regeneration treatment (
Section S1.2
). Each batch reaction (5 mM 4-C
8
H
16
, 0.1 M H
2
O
2
, 0.39 M H
2
O in CH
3
CN) was conducted for 30 min. The used catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation at 400 rpm for 10 min. Then the recovered solid catalyst was dried at 338 K for 30 min and heated to 823 K for 6 h in flowing dry air to remove water and organic species. The W content of the regenerated catalyst was determined by EDXRF and compared to that of the fresh catalyst. The catalyst was then reused for the subsequent reaction.
Figure S2
shows that the W content remained constant at 0.50 ± 0.006% by weight throughout the course of the four reactions, and the turnover rate was consistently 2.6 ± 0.2 (mmol C)(mol W s)
−1
for all four reactions. The consistency of these values demonstrates that the WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalysts are stable under these reaction conditions.

div.h3: 2.5. Active Site Titrations with Phenyl Phosphonic Acid
div.div:
The number of active sites in each catalyst was determined by in situ titrations with phenyl phosphonic acid (PPA, Sigma-Aldrich, 98%) during oxidative cleavage of 4-C
8
H
16
(0.025 M 4-C
8
H
16
, 0.1 M H
2
O
2
, 333 K) or oleic acid (0.1 M oleic acid, 0.5 M H
2
O
2
, 343 K). Briefly, the reactant (i.e., 4-C
8
H
16
or oleic acid), the catalyst, hexane (an internal standard for GC analysis), and PPA were added to the CH
3
CN solvent and stirred for 1 h. During this period, PPA adsorbs to the active sites of these catalysts, where PPA inhibits catalysis. The catalytic reaction was initiated by adding H
2
O
2
, and the initial reaction rates were determined as a function of the molar ratio of PPA to W atoms. The number of active sites for each catalyst was determined by extrapolating linear regions of these plots to the abscissa, which provides the number of PPA and the ratio of PPA to W atoms required to completely suppress catalysis. This analysis assumes that one PPA molecule occupies a single active site.

The heat released upon 1,2-epoxyoctane adsorption onto W active sites was measured using an isothermal titration calorimeter (ITC) equipped with gold reference and sample cells (TA Instruments, NanoITC). Briefly, the tungsten oxide catalyst (40–80 mg of WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
or WO
3
) was suspended in 500 μL of CH
3
CN (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.8%) by sonicating for 20 min, and the suspension was used to fill the sample cell of the calorimeter. The residual suspension was dried in the loading vessel at 373 K for 12 h, and the weight difference after filling the sample cell was used to determine the amount of catalyst loaded into the calorimeter. The reference cell was filled with neat CH
3
CN.

The titration syringe was filled with a solution of 1,2-epoxyoctane (0.01 M; 1,2-C
8
H
16
O, Sigma-Aldrich, 98%) in CH
3
CN, and the system was thermally equilibrated prior to the start of the experiment. Injections (1 μL) were made at regular intervals (300 s) in each experiment, which allowed the system to return to the baseline heating rate prior to the subsequent injection. Data analysis was performed with the NanoAnalyze software package (TA Instruments). The number of W sites available for titration was determined using the mass of the catalyst in the sample cell and the number of W active sites per gram (quantified by phenyl phosphonic acid titrations). Heats of adsorption are presented as a function of the fractional coverage of 1,2-C
8
H
16
O ((moles of 1,2-C
8
H
16
O)(W sites)
−1
).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3:
3.1. Nature of Supported WO
x
on γ-Al
2
O
3
div.div:
The series of
X
-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
samples synthesized that spans coverages from 0.03 to 0.9 W·nm
–2
(and associated mass loadings,
Table
1
) is expected to form predominantly isolated WO
x
complexes at the lowest coverages and oligomeric WO
x
species at the greatest coverages. γ-Al
2
O
3
was selected as a support in order to stabilize WO
x
complexes and suppress metal loss to the liquid phase during catalysis
(34)
and also because alumina does not catalyze epoxidation or oxidative cleavage reactions. The electronic, coordinative, and crystallographic structures of WO
x
complexes over γ-Al
2
O
3
depend upon the coverage of W atoms (W·nm
–2
) as shown by systematic changes in the band gap energies determined by DRUV–vis, the evolution of Raman features related to W═O and W–O–W coordination, and diffraction peaks apparent in XRD.

Figure
1
shows that the band gap energy increases as the surface coverage of WO
x
decreases from 0.9 to 0.06 W·nm
–2
, which indicates that the fraction of W atoms present at monomeric or small oligomeric WO
x
units is greater at lower coverages on γ-Al
2
O
3
. The band gap reaches a value of ∼4.85 eV for
X
-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
samples with surface coverage equal to or less than 0.06 W·nm
–2
. These band gaps are much greater than that for WO
3
(2.8 eV)
(35)
and together with the change in band gap with coverage suggest that materials with W atom coverages below 0.06 W·nm
–2
approach a constant distribution of WO
x
complexes, which likely contains a significant fraction of W atoms in monomer or dimer species.

In situ Raman spectroscopy was used to assess the structure of the WO
x
species on γ-Al
2
O
3
while in a dehydrated state and to determine these structures and also identify the reactive species formed by H
2
O
2
activation in solutions used for catalysis (0.5 M H
2
O
2
, 1.98 M H
2
O, CH
3
CN solvent, 313 K). The γ-Al
2
O
3
support does not give rise to any features visible in the Raman spectra
(36)
(
Figure S4
), which demonstrates that all peaks observed in
Figure
2
reflect vibrational modes that involve WO
x
. Raman spectra of dehydrated 0.03- and 0.06-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
samples contain a single detectable feature at 953 cm
–1
assigned to ν(W═O),
(37,38)
which signifies the presence of distorted [WO
4
]
−2
monotungstate. In contrast, Raman spectra of
X
-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
materials with greater W atom coverages (≥0.4 W·nm
–2
) possess this peak (i.e., ν(W═O)) but also exhibit Raman scattering features at 274, 719, and 809 cm
–1
that resemble δ(O–W–O), ν(W–O), and ν(O–W–O) modes, respectively, of the monoclinic WO
3
structure
(39)
that appear prominently in the spectra of WO
3
. Finally, Raman bands at 323 and 867 cm
–1
correspond to the δ(O–W–O) and ν(W–O–Al) of dehydrated surface oligomeric WO
x
, respectively. These findings suggest that dehydrated WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalysts contain predominantly monomeric WO
x
complexes at the lowest coverages and mixtures of oligomeric tungstate surface species and WO
3
aggregates at surface coverages of 0.4 W·nm
–2
and greater.

div.p:
Figure 2. In situ Raman spectra of WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
(0.03 (green line), 0.06 (blue line), 0.4 (orange line), and 0.9 (black line) W·nm
–2
) and WO
3
(red line) (a) under dry flowing helium (298 K, 101 kPa He) after dehydration (773 K, 1 h, 20 cm
3
·min
–1
) and (b) within flowing solutions of H
2
O
2
and CH
3
CN (0.5 M H
2
O
2
, 1.98 M H
2
O, 313 K, 1 cm
3
·min
–1
). Spectra are offset for clarity, and spectra obtained in the liquid phase are normalized using a feature of CH
3
CN at 920 cm
–1
.

div.div:
Figure
2
b shows steady-state Raman spectra of the catalysts within solutions of H
2
O
2
and CH
3
CN similar to those for kinetic measurements. All of these spectra contain strong Raman bands at 380 and 920 nm
–1
from CH
3
CN (e.g., δ(C–C≡N) and ν(C–C), respectively)
(40)
and a peak at 879 cm
–1
that corresponds to ν(O–O) of liquid-phase H
2
O
2
.
(41)
In situ Raman spectra of all
X
-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalysts exhibit peaks at 520, 556, 750, 953, and 600 cm
–1
that correspond to ν
s
(WO
2
),
(42,43)
ν
s
(W–O–W),
(44)
ν
as
(W–O–W),
(44)
ν(W═O),
(37,38)
and ν
as
(WO
2
)
(42,43)
modes, respectively. The W–peroxo complexes (i.e., W–(η
2
-O
2
), 520 and 600 cm
–1
) will be described in detail later (
Section 3.2
). Features for ν(W–O–W) appear in aqueous H
2
O
2
solution even at the lowest W atom coverages (≤0.06 W·nm
–2
) despite the absence of this peak on the dehydrated materials. Wachs et al. examined WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
materials with a similar range of surface coverage (0.5–4.5 W·nm
–2
) using a combination of Raman, DRUV–vis, and XANES analysis to determine the structure of WO
x
complexes in the presence and absence of coordinated water molecules.
(35,45)
Analysis of these results concluded that hydration of WO
x
induces mobility and permits dimerization and formation of W–O–W linkages observable by Raman.
(45)
Comparisons between Raman spectra (
Figure
2
) and measured band gaps (
Figure
1
) suggest, therefore, that these
X
-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
materials with W atom coverages equal to and less than 0.06 W·nm
–2
contain primarily WO
x
monomers when dehydrated but form a noticeable fraction of dimer complexes under the reaction conditions. The Raman spectra of the hydrated
X
-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
materials with high W coverages (≥0.4 W·nm
–2
) show the same peaks found on those under dehydrated conditions.

X-ray diffractograms confirm the presence of crystalline WO
3
particles on WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
samples with greater W atom coverages (
Figure S5
). All
X
-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
materials give diffraction features that correspond to γ-Al
2
O
3
(JCPDS No. 29-0063); however, the 0.9-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalyst exhibits additional weak XRD peaks that match those for crystalline WO
3
(JCPDS No. 83-950). These diffraction features were absent from all catalysts with W atom surface coverages less than 0.9 W·nm
–2
, which suggests that the Raman features reminiscent of WO
3
on 0.4-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
reflect poorly ordered WO
3
oligomers. Taken together, the results from DRUV–vis, in situ Raman, and XRD strongly suggest that samples with the lowest W atom surface coverages (≤0.06 W·nm
–2
) stabilize predominantly monomeric and dimeric WO
x
complexes under catalytic conditions. Significant fractions of W atoms reside as WO
x
oligomers at surface coverages between 0.06 and 0.4 W·nm
–2
, and crystalline WO
3
nanoparticles also form at greater W atom coverages. Consequently, we compare reactive intermediates, chemical interrogation of active sites, and rates of oxidative cleavage between 0.06-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
(designated hereafter as WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
) and WO
3
to understand how differences between the coordination and structure of WO
x
complexes affect the surface chemistry relevant for oxidative cleavage reactions.

div.h3:
3.2. Reactive Intermediates Derived from H
2
O
2
div.div:
As discussed in the previous section (
Section 3.1
),
Figure
2
b shows representative Raman spectra of
X
-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
and WO
3
in contact with a solution of H
2
O
2
in CH
3
CN (0.5 M H
2
O
2
, 1.98 M H
2
O, CH
3
CN solvent, 313 K). All of these Raman spectra contain vibrational features at ∼520 and ∼600 cm
–1
, which correspond to the ν
s
(WO
2
) and ν
as
(WO
2
) modes, respectively.
(42,43)
Interpretation of the Raman spectra in
Figure
2
suggests that WO
x
complexes initially possess oxo groups (W═O), form W–(η
2
-O
2
) species on contact with H
2
O
2
, and likely return to their initial state following the consumption of W–(η
2
-O
2
) species.

The H
2
O
2
-derived complexes on W-containing catalysts include W–(η
2
-O
2
) and W–hydroperoxo (W–OOH),
(46)
and while W–OOH and other metal–hydroperoxos do not appear to possess Raman active vibrational modes,
(47,48)
these species provide distinguishable peaks in UV–vis spectroscopy that reflect the ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) energies of the complexes.
Figure
3
a shows steady-state UV–vis spectra of γ-Al
2
O
3
, WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
, and WO
3
while within the same solution (0.5 M H
2
O
2
, CH
3
CN, 313 K). These spectra reveal absorbance features from 200 to 300 nm, which reflect the presence of W–(η
2
-O
2
) and W–OOH species for both WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
and WO
3
catalysts.
(49,50)
Spectral deconvolution of the features indicates two bands at ∼230 and ∼255 nm; the lower energy features are known to correspond to M–OOH, while the higher energy peaks are assigned to the M–(η
2
-O
2
) for H
2
O
2
-activated metal oxide catalyst.
(27,47,51,52)
The broad band near 345 nm on WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
resembles a similar feature on bare γ-Al
2
O
3
after contact with aqueous H
2
O
2
and therefore corresponds to a H
2
O
2
-derived species on the alumina support. These spectra show that both WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
and WO
3
catalysts possess W–(η
2
-O
2
) and W–OOH after H
2
O
2
activation; however, WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
seems to stabilize a greater ratio of W–OOH to W–(η
2
-O
2
) than WO
3
, perhaps due to a greater local concentration of protons derived from Brønsted acid sites on the support.
(47)

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) UV–vis spectra of H
2
O
2
activated γ-Al
2
O
3
, 0.06-WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
, and WO
3
acquired in situ within flowing H
2
O
2
solution (0.5 M H
2
O
2
, 1.98 M H
2
O, 313 K, 1 cm
3
·min
–1
). Spectra are offset and normalized by the maximum absorbance value. (b) Coverages of H
2
O
2
-derived intermediates (determined from UV–vis peak areas) as a function of time for WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
and WO
3
. Background spectrum was obtained in CH
3
CN (1.98 M H
2
O, 313 K) before time is equal to zero.

div.div:
These in situ UV–vis spectra provide the means to examine the reversibility of H
2
O
2
activation over W atoms on the catalysts examined here (
Figure
3
b). First, the catalysts were exposed to a H
2
O
2
solution (0.5 M H
2
O
2
, 1.98 M H
2
O, CH
3
CN 1 mL·min
–1
) to establish steady-state coverages of W–(η
2
-O
2
) and W–OOH species at 313 K. Once the absorbance features become constant, the flowing solution was replaced with a pure CH
3
CN solution (1 mL·min
–1
) that did not contain H
2
O and H
2
O
2
and intensities of the absorbance features were monitored. The results indicate that W–(η
2
-O
2
) and W–OOH species form slowly (∼1 h) and desorb (or decompose) within 0.4 h on WO
3
. In comparison, the coverage of H
2
O
2
-derived intermediates saturates within 10 min on WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
, and the coverage of the W–(η
2
-O
2
) and W–OOH species remains nearly constant within pure CH
3
CN. These results suggest that the H
2
O
2
-derived intermediates form irreversibly on WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
but reversibly on WO
3
on these time scales.

div.h3: 3.3. Titrations of Active Sites for Oxidative Cleavage
div.div:
Accurate comparisons between the different forms of tungsten oxide catalysts require direct measurement of the number of active sites, which should be conducted during catalytic reactions. Phenyl phosphonic acid (PPA) and other phosphonic acids can be used for this purpose, because these species deprotonate and the conjugate base binds to Lewis acidic transition metal atoms and inhibits catalytic turnovers.
(53)
Figure
4
shows that the oxidative cleavage rate decreases as the ratio of phenyl phosphonic acid to the total number of W atoms increases over both WO
3
and WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalysts. While these rates decrease systematically, addition of PPA does not completely suppress catalysis on either material. The residual catalytic rates may be caused by two effects. First, the steric hindrance provided by PPA may reduce turnover rates significantly for titrated W sites; however, these sites may still possess a fraction of their catalytic reactivity.
(27)
Second, PPA may bind reversibly to a fraction of the active sites, and therefore, reactants may still bind to and react with a fraction of sites that remain free of PPA.
(53,54)

div.p:
Figure 4. Turnover rates for oxidative cleavage of 4-octene (0.025 M 4-octene, 0.1 M H
2
O
2
, 333 K) as a function of
n
PPA
/
n
W
for (a) WO
3
and (b) WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
. Lines represent linear fits.

div.div:
A linear extrapolation of these measurements at low coverages (
Figure
4
) provides an estimated for the number of active sites per gram of material.
Figure
4
a shows that this occurs when values of
n
PPA
(n
WO3
)
−1
approach (3.9 ± 0.1) × 10
–3
, which corresponds to an active site density of 17 μmol·g
–1
of catalyst. In comparison, titrations of the WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalyst show oxidative cleavage rates near zero at
n
PPA
(n
WO3
)
−1
values of 1.02 ± 0.14, indicating a site density of 28 μmol·g
–1
of total catalyst (
Figure
4
b). These results show, perhaps surprisingly, that the density of the active sites on the WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalysts can surpass those on pure WO
3
despite extremely low surface coverages of W atoms on the γ-Al
2
O
3
support. These differences originate from both the low surface area of the WO
3
(
Section 2.2
) and the fact that only small fractions of the exposed W atoms on WO
3
are catalytically active. The surface densities of W atoms on monoclinic WO
3
are 7.3, 6.9, and 7.1 W atoms·nm
–2
for the (001), (100), and (010) facets, respectively.
(55)
Yet, the surface density of the active sites on WO
3
is 1.09 sites·nm
–2
, as determined from the combination of PPA titrations and N
2
physisorption measurements. These results indicate that only ∼15% of all surface W atoms of WO
3
are active for oxidative cleavage of 4-C
8
H
16
with H
2
O
2
. In comparison, the surface density of the W atoms of WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
is 0.06 W atoms·nm
–2
, and nearly all W atoms catalyze steps for oxidative cleavage (i.e., ∼0.06 sites·nm
–2
). This finding, along with the analysis of in situ Raman spectra (
Figure
2
b), suggests that the active sites include a combination of oligomeric and monomeric tungstate species. Notably, the surface density of the W atoms on γ-Al
2
O
3
can be increased to larger values while maintaining a high dispersion of these sites (
Figures
1
and
2
).

The greater number of active sites per gram of catalyst not only represents one advantage of the supported catalyst over WO
3
but also in later comparisons of turnover rates and activation enthalpies demonstrate that the WO
x
complexes on γ-Al
2
O
3
provide more favorable kinetics for the oxidative cleavage than WO
3
.

div.h3: 3.4. Reaction Pathways and Site Requirements for Oxidative Cleavage of 4-Octene
div.div:
Scheme 2
shows individual balanced reactions that lead to the oxidative cleavage of 4-octene and includes the Lewis acid-catalyzed epoxidation of 4-octene by reaction with H
2
O
2
, Brønsted acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of 4,5-epoxyoctane to yield 4,5-octanediol, and C–C bond cleavage of 4,5-octanediol to form two equivalents of butanal, potentially through an alpha-hydroxy ketone intermediate as described by Venturello et al.
(56)
The initial epoxidation of 4-octene occurs readily on WO
3
and WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalysts in the presence of H
2
O
2

2

Subsequently, the protonated intermediate reacts with water to irreversibly hydrolyze the epoxide and form 4,5-epoxyoctanediol (step 9), which desorbs (step 10). Finally, a closed series of steps converts 4,5-epoxyoctanediol to an alpha-hydroxy ketone intermediate by reaction with the basic solvent and then cleaves the C–C bonds following nucleophilic attack of H

These processes (step 11) must occur homogeneously within the solvent because rates for the oxidative cleavage of diols remain constant in the absence or presence of any of the catalysts examined here (

div.h3: 3.6. Effects of W Site Structure on Turnover Rates for Oxidative Cleavage
div.div:
The reference state and the transition state for oxidative cleavage can be theoretically be related by the transition-state theory (TST).
(57)
The apparent activation enthalpies can be used to compare the relative stability of the transition states over two different catalysts. TST proposed that W–OO (W–(η

Linear free-energy relationships provide a quantitative relationship between the chemical reactivity of a complex and its structure.

Noticeably, formation of the transition state structure for 4-octene epoxidation (i.e., the kinetically relevant process for oxidative cleavage) reproduces many of the changes in the coordinative structure of the active site and the surrounding solvent molecules as does adsorption of 1,2-epoxyoctane, an available mimic (

. The resulting high coverages of oleic acid on WO
3
(a consequence of both concentration and equilibrium constants) appear to inhibit the rates at which the epoxide product binds to protic sites (step 8,
Scheme 3
) and undergoes hydrolysis (step 9,
Scheme 3
). Consequently, the selectivity toward the epoxide remains high on WO
3
over the full range of reaction times (
Figure S8c
). The underlying reasons for this difference are not entirely clear. Measured Δ
H
Ads,epox
values (
Table
2
) indicate that the sites on WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
possess greater Lewis acid strength than those on WO
3
, which seems at odds with the weaker binding of the carboxylate of oleic acid (i.e., the conjugate base). However, this discrepancy may allude to important features of the adsorption mode (e.g., bidentate or monodentate) that stabilize this adsorbate on an ordered surface of WO
3
more so than on isolated WO
x
on γ-Al
2
O
3
. Greater understanding of the cause for these differences will likely require the use of in situ infrared spectroscopy to examine the coordination of the organic reactive intermediates to W active sites.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We synthesized a series of γ-Al
2
O
3
-supported tungstate catalysts with increasing W content via grafting methods to introduce isolated and oligomeric WO
x
species on γ-Al
2
O
3
. While Raman results of dehydrated materials show large fractions of WO
x
monomers, in situ Raman, DRUV–vis, and XRD results suggest that even the lowest W atom coverages lead to catalysts with mixtures of monomeric and dimeric WO
x
species under the reaction conditions. Raman spectroscopy suggests that W═O intermediates exist prior to H
2
O
2
exposure, but these species do not react with the C═C bonds to form measurable quantities of products. Instead, W–peroxide complexes (W–peroxo (W–(η
2
-O
2
))), formed by H
2
O
2
activation, react with alkenes to initiate steps that ultimately result in oxidative cleavage. The formation of W–peroxide complexes occurs irreversibly in the presence of alkene coreagents in CH
3
CN solution because these complexes react to epoxidize the alkene much more quickly than they desorb.

Kinetic measurements show that W–(η
2
-O
2
) transfers O atoms to C═C bonds to form epoxides, and the epoxidation step is consistently a kinetically relevant step for 4-octene and oleic acid conversions with H
2
O
2
. Acidic W–OOH functions then protonate and hydrolyze the epoxide to form the diol, and subsequently, oxidative cleavage proceeds via a homogeneous reaction between an alpha-hydroxy ketone and H
2
O
2
in the liquid phase. The spectroscopic and catalytic results suggest that the reaction pathway responsible for oxidative cleavage is identical on WO
3
and WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalysts, as are the rate expressions. Turnover rates for oxidative cleavage of 4-octene, however, are 75% greater over WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
than those over WO
3
at identical kinetic regimes. The activation enthalpies for this reaction over WO
3
and WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
catalysts are 60 ± 6 and 36 ± 3 kJ·mol
–1
, respectively. The differences between
ΔH
‡
on these catalysts correlate with differences in the Lewis acid strength of these active sites and their enthalpies of adsorption for the epoxide intermediate (
ΔH
ads,epox
) as measured by isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC). These comparisons suggest that the isolated W sites give greater turnover rates, particularly at lower reaction temperatures, because alumina-supported WO
x
species possess greater electronegativities, bind epoxide products more strongly, and stabilize kinetically relevant transition states more effectively than W atoms exposed on WO
3
.

While the pathways and mechanisms for the oxidative cleavage of oleic acid resemble those for 4-octene oxidative cleavage, selectivities differ significantly over WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
and WO
3
catalysts. WO
3
mainly produces the 8-(3-octyloxiran-2-yl)octanoic acid (epoxide), while WO
x
–Al
2
O
3
gives high selectivities for oxidative cleavage products (i.e., acids and aldehydes). These differences reflect the limited number of protic sites and competitive adsorption of oleic acid to the W atoms on the WO
3
surface, which appears to prevent the epoxide from reacting with W–OOH complexes as required for hydrolysis.

These findings demonstrate that solid tungstate catalysts are effective materials for oxidative cleavage reactions: these materials give significant turnover rates for key elementary steps (e.g., H
2
O
2
activation, epoxidation, and diol hydrolysis). The form of the solid tungstate site (i.e., WO
x
) matters, however, because the oxide on which these active sites exist determines the effective electron affinity (i.e., Lewis acid strength), the barriers for epoxidation, and preferences to bind individual reactive intermediates. The supporting oxide also controls the number of protonated intermediates available to assist in the hydrolysis of the epoxide ring. Consequently, both turnover rates and product selectivities are sensitive to the surface that supports the WO
x
site. From a practical perspective, efforts to increase rates and selectivities must also consider the ability of the support to maintain the dispersion of WO
x
sites (i.e., suppress oligomerization and formation of WO
3
nanoparticles) and prevent dissolution of W atoms into the reactant solution. For these reasons, we expect that there are significant opportunities to further improve the performance of solid tungstate catalyst for H
2
O
2
-mediated oxidative cleavage reactions.

Transition metal-catalyzed oxidative double bond cleavage of simple and bio-derived alkenes and unsaturated fatty acids
Spannring, Peter; Bruijnincx, Pieter C. A.; Weckhuysen, Bert. M.; Klein Gebbink, Robertus J. M.

A review. The oxidative cleavage of the C=C double bond in unsatd. fatty acids into aldehydes or carboxylic acids is a reaction of current interest in biomass valorization. The products of this reaction, which is currently being performed on an industrial scale by means of ozonolysis, can be applied for the prodn. of commodity chems. such as plasticizers and polymers. Alternative, catalytic methods for this conversion that are not based on the hazardous ozone oxidant are of high interest. In this respect, the use of transition metal catalysts would allow the application of milder reaction conditions and more benign oxidants. This review covers the various transition metal-based catalysts that have been reported for the oxidative cleavage of alkenes in general and the cleavage of unsatd. fatty acids in particular. Catalytic systems based on second- and third-row metals such as Ru, Os, and W have been widely studied and are well-known to catalyze the cleavage of various alkenes and unsatd. fatty acids. In addn. to simple metal salts, metal oxides or peroxides, various metal coordination complexes have been investigated for chemo- and regioselective olefin cleavage. Heterogeneous catalyst systems based on these metals have, in addn., been studied with a focus on catalyst reuse. To circumvent the use of expensive, toxic or less abundant second- and third-row metal catalysts, the use of first-row transition metal catalysts for the cleavage reaction might be preferred. However, examples of such catalysts for oxidative olefin cleavage are much less documented. The application of Fe- and Mn-based catalysts currently is largely limited to activated alkenes, e.g. styrene derivs. The many possibilities that are offered by careful ligand design together with the recent advances in the field of first-row transition metal oxidn. catalysis may allow for the development of catalyst systems that substitute ozone or second- and third-row metal catalysts for the oxidative cleavage of simple alkenes and unsatd. fatty acids.

New environmentally friendly oxidative scission of oleic acid into azelaic acid and pelargonic acid
Godard, Anais; Caro, Pascale; Thiebaud-Roux, Sophie; Vedrenne, Emeline; Mouloungui, Zephirin

This work was focused on the oxidative scission of oleic acid (OA), which yields a mono-acid (pelargonic acid, PA) and a di-acid (azelaic acid, AA) through an emulsifying system. The conventional method for producing AA and PA consists of the ozonolysis of OA, a process which presents numerous drawbacks. Therefore, we proposed to study a new alternative process using a green oxidant and a solvent-free system. OA was oxidized in a batch reactor with a biphasic org.-aq. system consisting of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30 %) as an oxidant and a peroxo-tungsten complex Q3{PO4[WO(O2)2]4} as a phase-transfer catalyst/co-oxidant. Several phase-transfer catalysts were prepd. in situ from tungstophosphoric acid, H2O2 and different quaternary ammonium salts (Q+, Cl-). The catalyst [C5H5N(n-C16H33)]3{PO4[WO(O2)2]4} was found to give the best results and was chosen for the optimization of the other parameters of the process. This optimization led to a complete conversion of OA into AA and PA with high yields (>80 %) using the system OA/H2O2/[C5H5N(n-C16H33)]3{PO4[WO(O2)2]4} (1/5/0.02 molar ratio) at 85°C for 5 h. In addn., a new treatment was developed in order to recover the catalyst.

The interest in renewable products is growing as a source of raw materials. Alongside, new process technologies (process intensification combined with continuous manufg.) are seen as better alternatives to increase the profitability of new projects. Consequently, two Monte Carlo simulations were performed to focus the Research and Development effort on areas of major impact on the development of a chem. process. Palm oil and high oleic sunflower oil were used as case studies for the prodn. of azelaic acid. It was found that process intensification strategies should focus on selectivity and on the redn. of the no. of processing steps. Addnl., the use of vegetable oils with a higher quality although at higher price (about 50% more expensive) provides a faster payback time, mostly due to a lower CAPEX and a better value of the co-products. For specialty chems., the choice of the oil depends strongly on the fatty acid profile.

Liq.-phase catalytic oxidn. of oleic acid with H2O2 in the presence of various transition metal/metal oxide catalysts was studied in a batch autoclave reactor. Azelaic and pelargonic acids are the major reaction products. W and Ta and their oxides in supported and unsupported forms were used as catalysts. Al2O3 pellets and Kieselguhr powder were used as supports for the catalysts. Mo, Zr and Nb also were examd. as catalysts. Exptl. results concluded that W and WO3 are the most suitable catalysts in terms of activity and selectivity. The rate of reaction obsd. in the case of supported catalysts is comparable or superior to that of unsupported catalysts. In pure form, W, Ta and Mo showed strong catalytic activity in the oxidn. reaction; however, except for Ta, they are economically unfeasible.

The oxidative cleavage of alkenes leads to the formation of carboxylic acids. One of the few tech. processes using this reaction is the prodn. of azelaic acid via the ozonolysis of oleic acid. Because of the need for stoichiometric amts. of the expensive oxidant ozone, together with safety hazards, there is still a requirement for a catalytic process using a cheap and environmentally friendly oxidant. In the present work, the oxidative cleavage of Me oleate by hydrogen peroxide was catalyzed by an easily available ruthenium precursor with dipicolinic acid as ligand. The systematic optimization of the reaction led to the formation of azelaic acid monomethyl ester in high yields amounting to 86%. The investigation of the reaction pathway showed that the reaction proceeds via a tandem reaction of epoxidn. and hydrolysis of the epoxide and oxidative cleavage of the vic-diol.

Recent trends in the development of sustainable catalytic systems for the oxidative cleavage of cycloalkenes by hydrogen peroxide
Cousin, Tony; Chatel, Gregory; Kardos, Nathalie; Andrioletti, Bruno; Draye, Micheline
Catalysis Science & Technology

Dicarboxylic acids constitute one of the most important oxygenated intermediates in the chem. industry providing a wide range of daily products: fibers, pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, lubricants, pesticides and plasticizers. A major part of their large-scale prodn. relies on the oxidative cleavage processes of unsatd. acids and cyclic olefins but suffers from severe drawbacks such as the use of harmful compds., the need of specific set-ups to produce oxidants, expensive catalysts and energy-consuming conditions. In the context of the development of sustainable oxidn. reactions, hydrogen peroxide has attracted growing interest thanks to its multiple benefits to replace conventional oxidants: low toxicity, no need of energetic conditions to perform catalytic oxidn. and generation of benign H2O as a byproduct. The present review aims at bringing a crit. view on the development of catalytic systems for the H2O2-mediated oxidative cleavage of cycloalkenes toward green chem. criteria. Different transition metal-based catalysts investigated for the reaction will be discussed with a special emphasis on tungsten. Next, the performance of different heterogeneous and homogeneous W-based systems on the oxidative cleavage of various cycloolefins will be presented. More specifically, their relevance towards sustainable oxidn. will be assessed by studying key reaction features: solvent, H2O2 amt., reaction time and catalyst synthesis, recoverability and activity. The main challenges regarding the oxidative cleavage of medium-sized cycloalkenes with W-H2O2 systems will also be exposed. Finally, the potential of ultrasound as an unconventional activation method will be pointed out to overcome the limits encountered with the conventional thermal heating leading to even more environmentally-friendly cycloalkene oxidative cleavage.

Spannring, Peter; Yazerski, Vital; Bruijnincx, Pieter C. A.; Weckhuysen, Bert M.; Klein Gebbink, Robertus J. M.

A one-pot method has been developed for the oxidative cleavage of internal alkenes into aldehydes by using 0.5 mol % of the nonheme iron complex [Fe(OTf)2(mix-bpbp)] (bpbp=N,N'-bis(2-picolyl)-2,2'-bipyrrolidine) as catalyst and 1.5 equiv of hydrogen peroxide and 1 equiv of sodium periodate as oxidants. A mixt. of diastereomers of the chiral bpbp ligand can be used, thereby omitting the need for resoln. of its optically active components. The cleavage reaction can be performed in one pot within 20 h and under ambient conditions. Addn. of water after the epoxidn., acidification and subsequent pH neutralization are crucial to perform the epoxidn., hydrolysis, and subsequent diol cleavage in one pot. High aldehyde yields can be obtained for the cleavage of internal aliph. double bonds with cis and trans configuration (86-98 %) and unsatd. fatty acids and esters (69-96 %). Good aldehyde yields are obtained in reactions of trisubstituted and terminal alkenes (62-63 %). The products can be easily isolated by a simple extn. step with an org. solvent. The presented protocol involves a lower catalyst loading than conventional methods based on Ru or Os. Also, hydrogen peroxide can be used as the oxidant in this case, which is often disproportionated by second- and third-row metals. By using only mild oxidants, overoxidn. of the aldehyde to the carboxylic acid is prevented.

A mild, organometallic alternative to ozonolysis utilizing oxone and OsO4 is presented. This is a direct oxidn. of olefins via the carbon-carbon cleavage of an osmate ester by the action of oxone. Free alcs., acetyl- and benzyl-protected alcs., and 1,2-diols were stable under these conditions. For e.g., cis-stilbene underwent OsO4-promoted catalytic oxidative cleavage to give benzoic acid in 95% yield. This method should be applicable for traditional org. synthesis.

A novel amphiphilic dipyridinium peroxophosphotungstate ion pair was developed as a selective and recyclable catalyst for the triphasic epoxidn. of fatty acids and esters with hydrogen peroxide. The synthesis of the catalyst was studied extensively by solid and liq. phase 31P NMR (NMR). The oxidn. of vegetable oils is of prime importance for the prodn. of lubricants, plasticizers, polymer stabilizers and other olefinic compds. Based on the oxidizing activity of peroxophosphotungstates, a lipophilic phase transfer agent that renders the active complex insol. in the reaction media, without having to support it on a matrix is developed. This affords a catalyst combining the activity of homogeneous catalysts and the recyclability of heterogeneous systems. This catalyst is able to fully epoxidize Me oleate with excellent selectivity, with a turnover frequency of 149 at 60°, and can be easily recycled, to reach a record turn over no. of 1868. A larger scale expt. on 13 g and a scope including linoleic and ricinoleic acids were also demonstrated. The catalyst also shows excellent activity and selectivity for the oxidative cleavage of Me oleate and the oxidn. of small olefins.

The scope of the oxidn. reactions of RuO4 (I) was investigated. I was prepd. by the slow addn. of N NaBrO3 to 4.37 g. RuCl3 (contg. 18% H2O) in 80 mL. refluxing 0.5N HCl, while I and H2O distd. into an ice-cooled receiver. I (55% yield) was then decanted and dissolved in CCl4 to give a deep red soln. Alcs. were oxidized rapidly by I to carbonyl compds. Thus, I in CCl4 was added to 1.50 g. cyclohexanol in 10 mL. CCl4 at 10-15° (ice-cooling was required). After standing overnight at room temp. the mixt. gave 2.18 g. RuO2 and 93% (based on I) cyclohexanone. Similarly, the following compds. were prepd. from the corresponding alcs. in the indicated yields: l-menthone, 96%; 3-cholestanone, 49%; BzH, 90%. n-C6H13OH, however, gave only 10% n-C5H11CO2H even with excess alc. trans-1,2-Cyclohexanediol in H2O gave 15% dione (or oxo-alc.). Aldehydes were oxidized rapidly to acids to give 33% BzOH and 30% n-C6H13CO2H. Olefins were oxidized to aldehydes with C-C bond cleavage, in contrast to OsO4 which gave diols. Thus, cyclohexene gave 10% adipaldehyde and 1-octene gave 12% n-C6H13CHO and (presumably) CH2O. The low yields were possibly due to the difficulty in sepg. the products from RuO2. Me cyclopropyl ketone reacted little, if at all, with I. A unique reaction of I was the oxidn. of ethers to esters. Thus, 2.55 g. Bu2O and 1.91 g. I in CCl4 gave a quant. yield of PrCO2Bu, while THF gave a nearly quant. yield of γ-butyrolactone which could not be oxidized further. An attempted oxidn. of ethylene oxide at 0° in CCl4 to an α-lactone (II) gave only a polymer, possibly derived from II. Tetrahydrofurfuryl alc. gave a compd., possibly an aldehyde lactone, forming a dinitrophenylhydrazone. Although esters were stable to I, amides were oxidized to imides. Thus, 1.33 g. γ-butyrolactam and 1.69 g. I gave 49% succinimide. N-Heptanoyl-n-hexylamine similarly gave an imide. C6H6 and EtCHMePh gave immediate reactions with I to yield unidentified carbonyl compds. C5H5N, (PhCH2)2, Ph3CH, tetrahydronaphthalene, 1-O2NC10H7, (PhN:)2, PhC≡CH, and (PhC≡)2 also gave immediate reactions but no isolated products. Slower reactions of I with Am3N, Et2NH, and piperidine apparently gave amides, while n-C6H13NH2 apparently did not. Ru is less volatile, less toxic, less expensive, and more readily available than Os.

Among these complexes, the novel PW2 anion was studied in the cryst. state and in soln. Several salts of the general formula Q2[HPO4{WO(O2)2}2] were obtained by the reaction of tungstic acid, H2WO4, or H3[PW12O40]·H2O with hydrogen peroxide, orthophosphoric acid, and the appropriate onium salt, QX (Q+ = [(n-C4H9)4N]+; [{(C6H5)3P}2N]+; [{(C18H37) 75% + (C16H33) 25%}2N(CH3)2]+). The structure of [(n-C4H9)4N]2[HPO4{WO(O2)2}2] (triclinic P‾1, a = 10.660(3) Å, b = 12.662(3) Å, c = 17.723(3) Å, α = 74.92(2)°, β = 77.57(2)°, γ = 86.65(2)°, Z = 2) was refined to R = 0.060 and Rw = 0.065. The polyanion has one nonbridging and one bridging peroxo group on each W center with slightly elongated peroxo bonds (1.53(3) and 1.56(4) Å) in the former case. The structural features compare well with those of previously described complexes, [(n-C6H13)4N]3[PM4O24] (M = Mo or W). The vibrational (IR and Raman) and 31P with 183W NMR spectra suggest that the overall structure is maintained in org. solvents at room temp. (R)-(+)-Limonene is stoichiometrically epoxidized at this temp. The two tungsten(VI) compds. [(n-C4H9)4N]2[HPO4{WO(O2)2}2] and [(n-C4H9)4N]3[PW4O24], are about 30 times more active than [(n-C4H9)4N]3[PMo4O24]. These differences an be related to the obsd. ν(O-O) frequencies (IR and Raman, both solid-state and soln. spectra).

The prodn. of valuable mono- and dicarboxylic acids from abundant and renewable vegetable oil sources is of great industrial interest. It is demonstrated by a simple and eco-friendly heterogeneous catalytic system for direct oleic acid (OA) cleavage by hydrogen peroxide to produce azelaic acid (AA) and nonanoic acid (NA). Com. available tungsten oxide was used as a heterogeneous catalyst without any modification or pretreatment, and sodium stannate was used as a H2O2 stabilizer to improve the efficiency of the oxidant. The sodium stannate additive notably improved the product yields and it could be recycled together with the tungsten oxide catalyst. Isolated product yields up to 89% for azelaic acid and 65% for nonanoic acid were achieved from oleic acid in this simple system, which should be among the best results for oleic acid cleavage in heterogeneous systems. This strategy is also applicable for other catalytic systems for the cleavage of OA or its derivs. This work provides a potential method for the large scale upgrading of oleic acid.

The oxidative cleavage of alkenes to carboxylic acids with 40% w/v aq. hydrogen peroxide catalyzed by methyltrioctylammonium tetrakis(oxodiperoxotungsto)phosphate(3-) (I) is reported to occur in high yields and selectivities under two-phase conditions in the absence of org. solvents. On the basis of a study of the reaction, two main reaction pathways leading to acids have been recognized, the first one involving the perhydrolysis and the second one the hydrolysis of the epoxide initially formed. The "perhydrolytic" reaction pathway appears to play a primary role in the oxidn. of medium- and long-chain alkenes to acids, while it intervenes to a rather limited extent in the oxidn. of arylalkenes and C5-C7 cycloalkenes. The occurrence of this pathway has been proved by the isolation of the intermediate β-hydroperoxy alcs. and their transformation into acids with H2O2 and I. The course of this transformation, involving an initial oxidn. (to α-oxo hydroperoxide) or decompn. (to carbonyl compds.) of the β-hydroperoxy alc. intermediate, is described. The primary oxidn. products, α-hydroperoxy ketones, have been isolated in the case of internal β-hydroperoxy alcs., whereas their presence has been evidenced with terminal β-hydroperoxy alcs. bearing a secondary hydroxy group. Hydrogen peroxide concn. appears to exert a remarkable influence on medium acidity, and its effects on the reaction efficiency are shown.

Alkene Epoxidations with H2O2 over Groups 4-6 Metal-Substituted BEA Zeolites: Reactive Intermediates, Reaction Pathways, and Linear Free-Energy Relationships
Ayla, E. Zeynep; Potts, David S.; Bregante, Daniel T.; Flaherty, David W.

(
1

CODEN:

Rates and selectivities for alkene epoxidns. depend sensitively on the identity of the active metal center for both heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts. While group 6 metals (Mo, W) have greater electronegativities and the corresponding mol. complexes have greater rates for epoxidns. than group 4 or 5 metals and mol. complexes, these relationships are not established for zeolite catalysts. Here, we combine complementary exptl. methods to det. the effects of metal identity on the catalytic epoxidn. of 1-hexene with H2O2 for active sites within the BEA framework. Postsynthetic methods were used to incorporate groups 4-6 transition-metal atoms (Ti, Nb, Mo, W) into the framework of zeolite BEA. In situ Raman and UV-vis spectroscopies show that H2O2 activates to form peroxides (M-(η2-O2)) and hydroperoxides (M-OOH) on all M-BEA but also metal oxos (M=O) on W- and Mo-BEAs, the latter of which leaches rapidly. Changes in turnover rates for epoxidn. as functions of reactant concns. and the conformation of cis-stilbene epoxidn. products indicate that epoxide products form by kinetically relevant O-atom transfer from M-OOH or M-(η2-O2) intermediates to the C=C bond and show two distinct kinetic regimes where H2O2-derived intermediates or adsorbed epoxide mols. prevail on active sites. Ti-BEA catalyzes epoxidns. with turnover rates 60 and 250 times greater than Nb-BEA and W-BEA, which reflect apparent activation enthalpies (ΔH‡) for both epoxidn. and H2O2 decompn. that are lower for Ti-BEA than for Nb- and W-BEAs. Values of ΔH‡ for epoxidn. differ much more between metals than barriers for H2O2 decompn. and give rise to large differences in 1-hexene epoxidn. selectivities that range from 93% on Ti-BEA to 20% on W-BEA. Values of ΔH‡ for both pathways scale linearly with measured enthalpies for adsorption of 1,2-epoxyhexane from the solvent to active sites measured by isothermal titrn. calorimetry. These correlations confirm that linear free-energy relationships hold for these systems, despite differences in the coordination of active metal atoms to the BEA framework, the identity and no. of pendant oxygen species, and the complicating presence of solvent mols.

The oxidn. of org. compds. by hydrogen peroxide, catalyzed by transition metal derivs., e.g. V(V), Mo(VI) and W(VI) complexes, involves the formation of peroxometal complexes. These are much more efficient oxidants than hydrogen peroxide so that the catalyzed reactions are of remarkable synthetic significance. Several peroxometal complexes can be isolated and used as stoichiometric oxidants. An appealing feature of these oxidants is their versatility, as demonstrated by the fact that they are able to oxidize substrates such as alkenes, alcs., ketones, sulfur, phosphorus and nitrogen derivs. and even arom. and aliph. hydrocarbons. Either polar or radical oxidns. may take place. The reactivity depends on the nature of the metal and esp. on the nature of the ligands coordinated to the metal. Therefore, an important goal consists in predicting the reactivity of peroxometal complexes on the basis of their structural features. Examples presented demonstrate that structure-reactivity correlations may be established. However, the effect of the ligands appears to be complex so that care must be exercised in drawing general conclusions. A review with >33 refs.

The synthesis of mesoporous siliceous solids with large-diam. channel apertures (25-100 Å) has greatly expanded the capabilities of heterogeneous catalysis. The large apertures in such mesoporous silicas can, for example, by modified by framework substitution to create highly selective catalysts. Here we show that direct grafting of an organometallic complex onto the inner walls of mesoporous silica MCM-41 generates a shape-selective catalyst with a large concn. of accessible, well spaced and structurally well defined active sites. Specifically, attachment of a titanocene-derived catalyst precursor to the pore walls of MCM-41 produces a catalyst for the epoxidn. of cyclohexene and more bulky cyclic alkenes.

Optical properties and electronic structure of amorphous germanium
Tauc, J.; Grigorovici, R.; Vancu, A.

(

CODEN:

The optical consts. of amorphous Ge are detd. for photon energies 0.08-1.6 ev. From 0.08 to 0.5 ev., the absorption is due to k-conserving transitions of holes between the valence bands as in p-type crystals; the spin-orbit splitting is 0.20 and 0.21 ev. in nonannealed and annealed samples, resp. The effective masses of the holes in the 3 bands are 0.49 m (0.43 m), 0.04 m, and 0.08 m. An absorption band is observed below the main absorption edge (at 300°K. the max. of this band is at 0.86 ev.); the absorption in this band increases with increasing temp. This band is due to excitons bound to neutral acceptors, and these are presumably the same ones that play a decisive role in the transport properties, which are considered to be assocd. with vacancies. The absorption edge has the form ω2ε2 ∼ (ℏω - Eg)2 (Eg = 0.88 ev. at 300°K.). This suggests that the optical transitions conserve energy but not k vector, and that the ds. of states near the band extrema have the same energy dependence as in cryst. Ge. A simple theory describing this situation is proposed, and comparison of it with the exptl. results leads to an estimate of the localization of the conduction-band wave functions. 24 references.

The transformation of Lewis acid sites to new Bronsted acid sites under hydrogen at 40 °C and atm. pressure on WO3/SiO2 and WO3/Al2O3 catalysts with various tungsten oxide loading (1, 5, 9, and 12 wt%) was investigated by the in situ DRIFTS of adsorbed NH3. The degree of Lewis acid transformation on WO3/SiO2 was higher than on WO3/Al2O3 because the weaker interaction between WO3 and SiO2 showed higher hydrogen accessibility as revealed by the H2-TPR and H2-TPD results. Moreover, Pt co-catalyst with supported tungsten oxide catalyst could enhance hydrogen uptake on WO3 catalyst, leading to higher Lewis acid transformation. However, the investigation of surface WO3 structures were obsd. by XRD, FT-Raman, UV-vis, and TEM to be the key point for allowing the Lewis acid transformation. After Lewis acid transformation, isolated tetrahedral WO3 were stable whereas octahedral polytungstate and cryst. WO3 decreased, converting to W4+ and W5+. The decreasing of cryst. WO3 after Lewis acid transformation was also found to be correlated well with the hydrogen uptake. Therefore, Lewis acid transformation on supported WO3 preferentially occurred on cryst. WO3 than on octahedral polytungstate WO3 and isolated tetrahedral WO3, resp.

Combined UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) and Raman spectroscopy were applied to examine the electronic and mol. structures, resp., of well-defined W(VI) bulk mixed oxide ref. compds. consisting of (i) isolated WO4 or WO6 monomers, (ii) dimeric O3W-O-WO3, (iii) polymeric chain of alternating WO4/WO6 units, and (iv) WO6-coordinated W9-W18 clusters. Raman spectroscopy was employed to confirm the identity and phase purity of the different tungsten oxide structures. UV-vis DRS provided the corresponding electronic edge energy (Eg) of the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transitions of the W(VI) cations. A correlation between the edge energy and the no. of covalent bridging W-O-W bonds around the central W(VI) cation was found with Eg linearly decreasing with increasing no. of bridging W-O-W bonds. However, a direct relationship between Eg and the domain size, NW, for finite WOx clusters does not exist. Subsequently, UV-vis and Raman spectroscopy information were applied to det. the local structures of the molecularly dispersed surface W(VI) species present in supported WO3/Al2O3, WO3/ZrO2, and WO3/SiO2 catalysts under ambient and dehydrated conditions.

A review. The mol. aspect of the Raman vibrational selection rules allows for the mol. structural and reactivity detns. of metal oxide catalytic active sites in all types of oxide catalyst systems (supported metal oxides, zeolites, layered hydroxides, polyoxometalates (POMs), bulk pure metal oxides, bulk mixed oxides and mixed oxide solid solns.). The mol. structural and reactivity detns. of metal oxide catalytic active sites are greatly facilitated by the use of isotopically labeled mols. The ability of Raman spectroscopy to (i) operate in all phases (liq., solid, gas and their mixts.), (ii) operate over a very wide temp. (-273 to >1000°) and pressure (UHV to »100 atm) range, and (iii) provide mol. level information about metal oxides makes Raman spectroscopy the most informative characterization technique for understanding the mol. structure and surface chem. of the catalytic active sites present in metal oxide heterogeneous catalysts. The recent use of hyphenated Raman spectroscopy instrumentation (e.g., Raman-IR, Raman-UV-vis, Raman-EPR) and the operando Raman spectroscopy methodol. (e.g., Raman-MS and Raman-GC) is allowing for the establishment of direct structure-activity/selectivity relationships that will have a significant impact on catalysis science in this decade. Consequently, this crit. review will show the growth in the use of Raman spectroscopy in heterogeneous catalysis research, for metal oxides as well as metals, is poised to continue to exponentially grow in the coming years.

Groups 5-7 transition metal oxides (V2O5, Nb2O5, Ta2O5, CrO3, MoO3, WO3, Re2O7) were anchored on a SiO2 support via incipient wetness impregnation and calcination. The mol. and electronic structures of the dehydrated supported metal oxides and the SiO2 support were detd. by combined in situ Raman, IR, and UV-vis spectroscopy under dehydrated conditions. In situ Raman characterization reveals that the supported metal oxides are only present as surface species below the max. dispersion limit (where cryst. metal oxide nanoparticles are absent). In situ IR anal. shows that the surface metal oxides anchor to the SiO2 support at Si-OH and adjacent Si-O-Si sites. The corresponding in situ UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy indicates that the dehydrated surface metal oxide species are present as isolated structures. Isotopic D2O-H2O exchange demonstrates that the dehydrated surface MOx species possess the M:O oxo functionality but no M-OH bonds. The no. of M:O oxo bonds was found to be related to the metal oxide oxidn. state or group no. The group 5 surface metal oxides are present as surface monoxo O:M(-O-Si)3 species. The group 6 surface metal oxides primarily contain the surface dioxo (O:)2M(-O-Si)2 structures with some surface monoxo O:MO4 species also present. In situ Raman under redn. environments allowed for the discrimination between these multiple MOx surface species as well as between vibrations from the metal oxides and the silica support. Only rhenia from the group 7 surface metal oxides was examd. and found to possess the surface trioxo (O:)3Re-O-Si structure. These mol. and electronic structural insights for dehydrated surface metal oxides on SiO2 catalysts will facilitate the establishment of fundamental structure-activity relationships for future catalytic reaction studies.

Metal oxides are suitable for detecting, through conductive measurements, a variety of reducing and oxidizing gases in environmental and sensing applications. Metal-oxide gas sensors can be developed with the goal of sensing gases under specific conditions and, as a whole, are heavily dependent on the manufg. process. W oxide (WO3) is a promising metal-oxide material for gas-sensing applications. The purpose of this paper is to det. the existence of a correlation between thermal effects and the changes in the Raman spectra for multiple WO3 structures. The authors have obtained results using Raman spectroscopy for 3 different structures of WO3 (monoclinic WO3 on Si substrate, nanopowder, and nanowires) that were subjected to temps. at 30-160°. The major vibrational modes of the WO3:Si and the nanopowder samples, located at ∼807, ∼716, and ∼271 cm-1, correspond to the stretching of O-W-O bonds, the stretching of W-O, and the bending of O-W-O, resp.; these are consistent with a monoclinic WO3 structure. However in the nanowires sample only asym. stretching of the W-O bonds occurs, resulting in a 750. cm-1 band, and the bending of the O-W-O mode (271 cm-1) is a stretching mode (239 cm-1) instead, suggesting the nanowires are not strictly monoclinic. The most notable effect of increasing the temp. of the samples is the appearance of the bending mode of W-OH bonds in the approx. range of 1550-1150 cm-1, which is related to O-H bonding caused by humidity effects. Features such as those at 750 cm-1 for nanowires and at 492 and 670 cm-1 for WO3:Si disappear as the temp. increases. A deeper understanding of the effect that temp. has on the Raman spectral characteristics of a metal oxide such as WO3 has helped to extend knowledge regarding the behavior of metal oxide-gas interactions for sensing applications. This, in turn, will help to develop theor. models for the identification of specific metal oxide-gas relations.

H2O2 concns. in aq. solns. were detd. by a 532 nm Raman spectrometer. H2O2 is a highly demanded green oxidant agent, and its direct synthesis from H2 and O2 is a promising alternative to the traditional prodn. process. Raman spectroscopy is a fast, nondestructive and reliable anal. technique for H2O2 quantification, which avoids the drawbacks of traditional iodometric detns. (sample extn., prepn. of the reagents and a long time of anal.). A high pressure view cell was designed to facilitate the measuring at high pressures, which are often found in a direct synthesis process. A thorough calibration model was developed, and it was validated at high pressure (5.0 MPa) and temp. (up to 45°). The solvent (water) was used as internal std. to correct multiplicative distortions. The validation of the anal. technique produced reproducible and accurate results compared against classic iodometric titrn., allowing the use of a single calibration model for a range of reaction conditions. The feasible use of Raman spectroscopy for real-time quant. reaction monitoring was established by analyzing the decompn. reaction of H2O2 under different conditions.
